questions.text: A 46-year-old man with HIV infection comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of severe retrosternal pain while swallowing. He has not been adherent to his antiretroviral drug regimen. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 98/mm3. Endoscopy shows white plaques in the esophagus. The most appropriate immediate treatment is a drug that inhibits which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of DNA polymerase is the mechanism of action of certain antiviral medications (e.g., ganciclovir and acyclovir) and antifungal medications (e.g., flucytosine). Ganciclovir and acyclovir are used to treat infections caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV) and cytomegalovirus (CMV). Although immunocompromised patients with decreased CD4+ counts are at increased risk of viral infection, viral esophagitis caused by CMV manifests with linear ulcers and esophagitis caused by HSV with circumscribed ulcers in the distal esophagus, in contrast to this patient's white plaques. Flucytosine can be used to treat systemic fungal infections when combined with amphotericin B and is particularly useful for the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis. It would not effectively treat esophageal candidiasis.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of H+/K+ ATPase, which decreases gastric acid production, is the mechanism of action of PPIs. PPIs are the first-line treatment for gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which manifests with retrosternal pain, odynophagia, and dysphagia, which are seen in this patient. However, GERD would not explain his white plaques, and PPIs play no role in the treatment of esophageal candidiasis.

C) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of phospholipase A2, an enzyme in the arachidonic acid synthesis pathway that leads to the formation of eicosanoids, is the mechanism of action of glucocorticoids. Glucocorticoids are prescribed for a variety of conditions, including hypersensitivity reactions, autoimmune conditions, and adrenal insufficiency. Because of their immunosuppressive effects, glucocorticoids are contraindicated in this patient; they would exacerbate his esophageal candidiasis and predispose him to further infections.

D) CORRECT:

Fluconazole is one of the first-line treatments for candida esophagitis. Fluconazole inhibits the yeast cytochrome p450 enzyme 14α-demethylase, which prevents ergosterol synthesis and therefore decreases cell membrane integrity, leading to cell destruction. It is also indicated for the treatment of systemic candidiasis, cryptococcal meningitis, and antifungal prophylaxis.
Image Description:

Polyenes bind to ergosterol in the cell membrane, creating pores that disrupt the electrolyte balance, which results in cell death.
Echinocandins inhibit the enzyme β-glucan synthase, which is essential for fungal cell wall synthesis.
Allylamine derivatives and azoles inhibit the synthesis of ergosterol, the main steroid of the fungal cell membrane.
Griseofulvin disrupts fungal mitosis by interfering with the function of microtubules.
Flucytosine, which is converted to 5-fluorouracil within the fungal nucleus, is an antimetabolite, as it inhibits the synthesis of DNA and RNA.

E) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of squalene epoxidase, an enzyme that synthesizes squalene epoxide from squalene, is the mechanism of action of the antifungal terbinafine. Squalene epoxide is necessary for the synthesis of lanosterol, which, in turn, is required to synthesize ergosterol, an important element of the fungal cell membrane. Terbinafine therefore causes fungal cell death by ultimately disrupting cell membrane integrity. However, terbinafine is indicated for superficial dermatophyte infections (e.g., onychomycosis, tinea), not candida esophagitis.
questions.hint: HIV infection with acute odynophagia, white plaques on upper GI endoscopy, and a low CD4+ T-cell count (especially < 100/mm3) are consistent with esophageal candidiasis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes to the physician because of white lesions in his mouth for 4 days. He also has pain while chewing food. He was diagnosed with non-Hodgkin lymphoma around 8 months ago. He is undergoing chemotherapy and is currently on his fourth cycle. He was treated for herpes labialis 4 months ago with acyclovir. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. He appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy is present. Oral examination shows white plaques on his tongue and buccal mucosa that bleed when scraped off with gauze. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Systemic fluconazole therapy can be used to treat patients with moderate to severe oropharyngeal candidiasis. However, oral rather than intravenous fluconazole is recommended for these patients. Intravenous fluconazole therapy is usually reserved for patients with esophageal candidiasis who cannot tolerate oral therapy or patients with systemic candidiasis.

B) INCORRECT:

Although culture of the lesions can be performed to diagnose oropharyngeal candidiasis, it is only used in recurrent or refractory disease to determine possible resistances as results usually take time. This is the patient's first episode of oral thrush and there are no indicators of unusual or resistant Candida species.

C) CORRECT:

Topical antifungal therapy (e.g., troches, mucoadhesive buccal tablets, pastilles) is considered first-line for most patients with oropharyngeal candidiasis. Preferred topical agents include clotrimazole, miconazole, and nystatin. Oral fluconazole is also used, most commonly in patients with moderate to severe symptoms.

The diagnosis of oropharyngeal candidiasis is most often clinical. KOH test and/or tissue culture are usually reserved for patients with inconclusive clinical findings. HIV testing should be performed in patients with no identifiable risk factors for oropharyngeal candidiasis.
Image Description:

Yellow-white cottage cheese-like plaques are visible on the inflamed oropharyngeal mucosa.

These white plaques are pathognomonic of oral candidiasis (oral thrush), an opportunistic infection caused by Candida albicans.

D) INCORRECT:

A biopsy of the lesion would be indicated in the case of suspected oral leukoplakia, a precancerous lesion, in which malignancy should be ruled out. While the white lesions of leukoplakia resemble oropharyngeal candidiasis and are common in tobacco users, they are usually asymptomatic and cannot be scraped off.
Image Description:

Poorly demarcated, white plaque on the buccal mucosa that cannot be scraped off.

This finding is most consistent with oral leukoplakia, which may develop into squamous cell carcinoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical corticosteroids are used in the treatment of severe aphthous stomatitis, a disease that manifests with painful oral ulcers covered by a yellow fibrinous pseudomembrane. White plaques that can be scraped off are not typical of the disease, making oral candidiasis more likely.
Image Description:

Two shallow spherical ulcers are visible on the buccal mucosa of the lower lip. The borders of the ulcer are erythematous and well defined. Healthy granulation tissue is visible on the floor of the ulcers.

These aphthous ulcers are typically painful and resolve spontaneously without scarring. Aphthous stomatitis is a condition characterized by recurrent episodes of aphthous ulcer formation.
questions.hint: White plaques on the oral mucosa that can be scraped off are suggestive of oropharyngeal candidiasis. Further common findings include pain when eating, loss of taste, and a cottony feeling in the mouth. Candida albicans infections most commonly affect immunocompromised individuals, e.g., patients with hematologic malignancies.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of progressive pain while swallowing. She has the feeling that food gets stuck in her throat and is harder to swallow than usual. She has a history of high-grade cervical dysplasia which was treated with conization 12 years ago. Four months ago, she was diagnosed with Graves' disease and started on antithyroid therapy. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She has had eight lifetime sexual partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Her father died of stomach cancer. She has never smoked and drinks one glass of wine daily. She uses cocaine occasionally. Her current medications include methimazole and a vitamin supplement. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. Examination of the oral cavity shows several white plaques that can be scraped off easily. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.9 g/dL


Leukocyte count
12,200/mm3



Platelet count
290,000/mm3



Prothrombin time
12 seconds


Partial thromboplastin time (activated)
38 seconds


Serum



Na+

135 mEq/L


Cl-

104 mEq/L


K+

4.9 mEq/L


Blood urea nitrogen
13 mg/dL


Glucose
90 mg/dL


Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL


 HIV antibody test
positive


In addition to starting antiretroviral therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical nystatin can be used to treat oral thrush. However, topical therapy is not effective for the treatment of esophagitis and is therefore not recommended in this patient with symptoms of concomitant Candida esophagitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic commonly used as a prophylactic drug and to treat disseminated Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) disease in HIV-positive patients. MAC disease manifests with fever, fatigue, diarrhea, weight loss, and/or pulmonary disease. Prophylaxis against MAC is started when the CD4+ count is ≤ 50/mm3 in patients who are not receiving antiretroviral therapy. However, MAC disease does not typically cause dysphagia and odynophagia, and these symptoms should be addressed first. Therefore, azithromycin would not be effective for this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Ganciclovir is an antiviral drug used to treat cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections. While CMV esophagitis can occur in HIV-positive patients and causes dysphagia, it is less common than fungal esophagitis. As this patient has oral thrush on examination, candida esophagitis is more likely. Therefore, ganciclovir is not indicated in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Methimazole is an antithyroid drug used to treat hyperthyroidism. This patient has clinical features of esophagitis and is immunocompromised. While there are drugs that can cause esophagitis (e.g., doxycycline, potassium chloride, NSAIDs) and symptoms similar to those seen in this patient, methimazole does not cause esophagitis. Its most serious complication is agranulocytosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Amphotericin B is an antifungal agent used to treat systemic fungal and protozoal infections. Amphotericin B is only used as a treatment for candidal esophagitis if the organism is resistant against first-line drugs or if there is recurrence of symptoms and an endoscopy is not desired. Therefore, amphotericin B is not indicated in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Although esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) can confirm the diagnosis of Candida esophagitis, most patients with clinical features of the condition and oral thrush on examination can be treated empirically with antifungal therapy. If symptoms do not resolve with empirical therapy, an EGD should be performed.

G) CORRECT:

Systemic antifungal therapy is the most appropriate treatment for patients with suspected Candida esophagitis. Oral fluconazole is the preferred regimen, but intravenous therapy is indicated in patients who do not tolerate oral therapy. Most patients with oral thrush and suspected Candida esophagitis can be treated empirically with systemic antifungal therapy. If symptoms do not resolve with empirical therapy, an EGD should be performed to rule out other causes of esophagitis.
questions.hint: This patient has white plaques that can be easily scraped off, indicating oral thrush. The presence of dysphagia suggests concomitant Candida esophagitis.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female college student comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of vaginal itching and burning. She also noticed white vaginal discharge despite cleaning her genital area daily using a "soap-free, natural" vaginal douche. She is worried that she might have contracted a sexually transmitted disease after meeting her new boyfriend around one month ago. She has type 1 diabetes mellitus. The patient swims for the college swimming team. She had an intrauterine device implanted 3 months ago and does not use barrier protection. She smokes one pack of cigarettes per day and does not drink alcohol. Speculum examination shows an erythematous vagina covered in copious white discharge. Her vaginal pH is 4.4 and the microscopic image of a potassium hydroxide preparation shows multiple pseudohyphae. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Smoking decreases the number of vaginal Lactobacillus species, has an antiestrogenic effect, and dysregulates immune function, making smokers more prone to bacterial vaginosis, which manifests with a gray or milky vaginal discharge that has a fishy odor. Discharge in candidal vulvovaginitis, on the contrary, is usually white, crumbly, and odorless. Smoking has not been shown to be a risk factor for vaginal yeast infection, although it is one for oral candidiasis in immunocompromised patients (e.g., patients with diabetes).

B) INCORRECT:

While swimming pools do not predispose to Candida infection in general, there is a debate about whether wearing damp, tight-fitting bathing suits for an extended period of time might create an optimal environment for yeast and promote overgrowth. However, another predisposing factor is much more significant in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Frequent vaginal douching to cleanse the inside of the vagina and the use of soaps with perfumes and irritating chemicals are risk factors for bacterial vaginosis because they disturb the normal vaginal microflora. Vaginal douching decreases the amount of lactic acid-producing lactobacilli, which leads to an increase in the pH balance. A pH higher than 4.5 is no longer acidic enough to prevent the proliferation of certain organisms, and contributes, e.g., to an increase in Gardnerella vaginalis.

D) INCORRECT:

Unprotected sexual intercourse is a risk factor for several sexually transmitted infections, such as trichomoniasis and Chlamydia. However, Candida overgrowth is commonly precipitated by other factors.

E) INCORRECT:

Intrauterine devices may be associated with gynecologic infections and pelvic inflammatory disease. However, the risk is very low, making another cause much more likely in this patient.

F) CORRECT:

Diabetes mellitus (DM) predisposes to vaginal yeast infections since high levels of glucose provide the carbon needed for Candida overgrowth and infection. Moreover, DM results in immunodeficiency, which is also associated with an increased risk of persistent or recurrent yeast infection. Other risk factors that precipitate overgrowth of C. albicans are systemic antibiotic therapy and pregnancy, in which case high levels of estrogen favor overgrowth by Candida. Treatment of acute infection consists of topical azoles (e.g., miconazole, clotrimazole) or a single dose of oral fluconazole. Maintaining normal blood sugar levels may help reduce the risk of recurrent or persistent infections in patients with DM.
Image Description:

Vaginal wet mount after potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation (microscopy) that shows Candida albicans forming multiple pseudohyphae (thin filamentous structures; examples indicated by blue overlay).

The prominent grey and white circles are optical artifacts.

White circles: examples of budding yeast
questions.hint: Multiple pseudohyphae on wet mount preparation are characteristic of Candida infection.

questions.text: A 4-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his father because of a progressively worsening rash on his buttocks for the last week. He cries during diaper changes and is more fussy than usual. Physical examination of the boy shows erythematous papules and plaques in the bilateral inguinal creases, on the scrotum, and in the gluteal cleft. Small areas of maceration are also present. A diagnosis is made, and treatment with topical clotrimazole is initiated. Microscopic examination of skin scrapings from this patient's rash is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Fruiting bodies with septate, acute-angle hyphae
Round yeast surrounded by budding yeast cells

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Narrow budding, encapsulated yeast on India ink staining indicates Cryptococcus neoformans infection. Cryptococcus neoformans infection is primarily seen in immunocompromised patients and can cause pneumonia, cryptococcal meningoencephalitis, and brain abscesses. Cryptococcus neoformans is not associated with diaper rash.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (India ink stain)

Numerous spherical yeast cells of different sizes can be seen. The polysaccharide capsules appear as yellowish halos around the cell walls (dark circles).

These features are characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans under light microscopy.

B) CORRECT:

Candida albicans appears as oval, budding yeast with pseudohyphae in skin scrapings of an infection. Candida albicans is part of the normal skin flora, but infection can occur when there is an imbalance that allows local Candida albicans overgrowth. Infants are often affected by Candida mucocutaneous infections in the anogenital region since overgrowth is facilitated by the prolonged damp and warm conditions of a diaper.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (200x magnification)

A cluster of yeast-like cells (arrowhead) is visible in the upper right corner of the image. Arising from this cluster are numerous pseudohyphae identifiable as long filamentous nonseptate structures (example indicated by a blue overlay). Asexual budding spores (blastospores; example indicated by red overlay) arise along the sides of the pseudohyphae. Thick-walled solitary circular chlamydospores (resting stage of Candida; example indicated by green overlay) arise from the tips of the pseudohyphae.

This coexistence of different morphological types (yeast cells, pseudohyphae, budding blastospores, and resting chlamydospores) is typical of Candida albicans.

C) INCORRECT:

Fruiting bodies with septate, acute-angle hyphae (45°) on tissue biopsy indicate Aspergillus fumigatus infection. Aspergillus fumigatus can cause allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), chronic pulmonary aspergillosis, invasive aspergillosis, and infective endocarditis. Although Aspergillus fumigatus can cause irritation of the skin in patients with ABPA, it is not associated with diaper rash.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Aspergillus fumigatus

Several buds are visible sprouting from the thread-like structure of the septate hyphae (green overlays). Buds are composed of a stalk (conidiophore; blue overlay) topped by a conidial head. The head consists of a central spherical vesicle (not visible here but indicated by yellow circle) surrounded by chains of prophialide (examples indicated by red arrowheads) and phialide projections (examples indicated by green arrowheads) with conidia tips (examples indicated by black arrowheads). The base is formed by a foot cell (red overlay).

D) INCORRECT:

Round yeast surrounded by budding yeast cells (captain's wheel) on KOH test (potassium hydroxide smear) indicates Paracoccidioides brasiliensis infection. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis infection is most often asymptomatic, but it can manifest with acute pneumonia, painful nasopharyngeal ulcerations, and verrucous skin lesions. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis is not associated with diaper rash.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Paracoccidioides brasiliensis (methenamine silver stain)

A circular cell with round budding daughter cells can be seen in the center of the image. This appearance (“pilot's wheel”) is characteristic of Paracoccidioides species. Additional Paracoccidioides cells that do not have the classic appearance can be seen in the upper left.

E) INCORRECT:

Broad-based budding yeast on KOH test (potassium hydroxide smear) indicates Blastomyces dermatitidis infection. This patient has a diaper rash and no evidence of systemic disease (e.g., pneumonia, flulike symptoms), making a Blastomyces dermatitidis infection highly unlikely.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of skin tissue sample (GMS stain)

Thick-walled fungi with single broad-based buds are visible.

This is the typical appearance of Blastomyces dermatitidis in yeast form (at body temperature, 37°C). At room temperature (∼ 23°C ), this dimorphic fungus exists in mold form.
questions.hint: This patient has typical signs of a diaper rash due to Candida albicans. It can be treated with a variety of topical antifungal agents such as clotrimazole.

questions.text: Four days after undergoing liver transplantation, a 47-year-old man develops fever, chills, malaise, and confusion while in the intensive care unit. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F). Blood cultures grow an organism. Microscopic examination of this organism after incubation at 25°C (77°F) for 3 hours is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aspergillus fumigatus may cause invasive infections in immunosuppressed patients and would appear as septate hyphae with acute-angle branching. However, since Aspergillus is a monomorphic fungus that only has a mold (hyphal) form, yeast cells would not be expected. Moreover, the hyphal elements of Aspergillus do not have constrictions at the septa. Instead, a specialized bulbous vesicle with a row of sprouting spores would be present at the end of hyphae. Finally, patients with invasive aspergillosis would typically have symptoms of acute necrotizing pneumonia (e.g., hemoptysis).
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Aspergillus fumigatus

Several buds are visible sprouting from the thread-like structure of the septate hyphae (green overlays). Buds are composed of a stalk (conidiophore; blue overlay) topped by a conidial head. The head consists of a central spherical vesicle (not visible here but indicated by yellow circle) surrounded by chains of prophialide (examples indicated by red arrowheads) and phialide projections (examples indicated by green arrowheads) with conidia tips (examples indicated by black arrowheads). The base is formed by a foot cell (red overlay).

B) CORRECT:

Candida albicans is a dimorphic fungus that appears as budding yeast cells with pseudohyphae at 20–25°C and forms germ tubes at 37°C. The formation of germ tubes can be used to differentiate C. albicans from other species of Candida as well as other yeasts. C. albicans typically causes mucocutaneous infections (e.g., oral thrush) but can result in disseminated hematogenous infection with clinical features of sepsis (e.g., fever, chills, malaise, confusion) in severely immunocompromised patients. Treatment of systemic infection consists of fluconazole, echinocandins, or amphotericin B.

C) INCORRECT:

Cryptococcus neoformans usually causes meningitis or encephalitis in severely immunocompromised patients (e.g., from HIV infection). Meningitis can manifest with fever, chills, malaise, and confusion. However, other symptoms, such as headache and neck stiffness, would also be expected. Furthermore, on microscopic examination, C. neoformans would appear as an encapsulated yeast without hyphae or pseudohyphae.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture

Numerous spherical yeast cells of different sizes are visible, with the polysaccharide capsules appearing in darker blue.

D) INCORRECT:

Immunosuppression can cause hematogenous dissemination of Blastomyces dermatitidis, which would also show branching, septated hyphal elements on microscopic examination after incubation at 25°C. However, the hyphal elements would be filamentous without constrictions at the septa, and microconidia would be present along the hyphae. Yeast cells would only be expected after incubation at 37°C. Moreover, blastomycosis would cause verrucous skin lesions or granulomatous nodules, which are not present in this patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a sputum specimen at 22°C (scale bar = 10 μm)

Several thick-walled, circular fungal cell bodies with filamentous structures containing germ tubes and hyphae are visible. The filaments indicate fungal germination, which only occurs at temperatures < 25°C.

This is the typical appearance of Blastomyces dermatitidis in mold form (at room temperature, ∼ 23°C). At body temperature (37°C), this dimorphic fungus exists in yeast form.

E) INCORRECT:

Immunosuppressed patients are at increased risk of infection by Mucor spp. (e.g., Mucor racemosus), which would grow rapidly at 25°C and appear as broad, branching hyphae. However, the hyphae would be aseptate and branch at 90° or obtuse angles unlike the septate hyphae with acute-angle branching seen here. Also, Mucor is a monomorphic fungus that only has a mold (hyphal) form; yeast cells would not be expected. Moreover, mucormycosis typically presents with features of fulminant destructive rhinosinusitis (e.g., headache, facial pain, black nasal discharge).
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of stomach tissue (H&E stain; 975x magnification)

A broad, nonseptate hypha can be seen branching into two hyphae at a wide angle of ∼ 90°.

Aseptate hyphae with unusually wide branching angles are characteristic features of mucormycosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Immunosuppression can cause hematogenous dissemination of Histoplasma capsulatum, which would show branching, septated hyphal elements after incubation at 25°C. However, the hyphal elements would be filamentous without constrictions at the septa; microconidia and tuberculated macroconidia would be present along the hyphae. Furthermore, yeast cells would only be present after incubation at 37°C. Finally, symptoms of histoplasmosis, such as hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and oral ulcers, would also be expected.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a soil specimen at 25°C (lactophenol cotton blue stain)

Numerous septated hyphae are visible throughout the image. The large, knobbly (tuberculated), dark blue spherical structures are the macroconidia. The small, smooth, pink spherical structures are the microconidia.

This is the typical appearance of Histoplasma capsulatum in mold (mycelial) form. At temperatures > 37°C, Histoplasma capsulatum exists in a yeast form.

G) INCORRECT:

Microscopic examination of Malassezia furfur would show round yeast-like cells and septated hyphal elements. However, the hyphal elements of M. furfur would be short, curved, and unbranched (“spaghetti-and-meatball” appearance), and M. furfur only grows in a narrow temperature range of 32–35°C. Moreover, M. furfur causes a superficial skin infection characterized by hypopigmented macules on the trunk (pityriasis versicolor). It typically does not cause a disseminated hematogenous infection.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a skin scraping

Throughout the image, there are multiple short, septated hyphae (filamentous structures) and spherical spores. These different morphological forms are responsible for the “spaghetti and meatballs” pattern (hyphae being the spaghetti and yeast being the meatballs), which is a typical finding of Malassezia furfur.
questions.hint: This patient who recently underwent liver transplantation is most likely on immunosuppressive therapy. The image shows multiple oval yeast cells with branching, septate hyphal elements. However, the presence of constrictions at the septa indicates that these are not true septate hyphae but rather pseudohyphae formed by the budding of yeast cells.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician with difficulty swallowing for several weeks. Examination of the oropharynx shows lesions on palate and tongue that can be easily scraped off. An image of the lesions is shown. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Oral thrush is caused by Candida albicans infection. The risk of mucocutaneous candidiasis is increased in patients with T-cell deficiency, which can occur in conditions such as HIV infection (↓ CD4+ T-cell count), severe combined immunodeficiency, and DiGeorge syndrome. Other risk factors for mucocutaneous candidiasis are uncontrolled diabetes mellitus, inhalation of corticosteroids, antibiotic use, and neonatal age group (Candida infection acquired during vaginal delivery). Mild oral thrush can be treated topically with nystatin (“swish and swallow”). The odynophagia seen in this patient could suggest involvement of the esophagus (candidal esophagitis). Severe thrush or candidal esophagitis will require systemic therapy with fluconazole or echinocandins.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhalation of corticosteroids (e.g., fluticasone in asthmatic patients) is a risk factor for oral thrush. Inhalation of salbutamol, a beta-2 agonist, is not a risk factor.

C) INCORRECT:

Missed childhood vaccination is a risk factor for measles, which would cause white lesions in the oral cavity called Koplik spots and possibly odynophagia in the prodromal phase. However, Koplik spots appear as pinhead-sized lesion on an erythematous base, unlike the patches seen in this patient, and they cannot be scraped off. Moreover, the prodromal phase would only last a few days before resulting in a maculopapular exanthem (unlike this patient with odynophagia for several weeks).
Image Description:

Numerous tiny white spots on an erythematous background (Koplik spots; examples indicated by arrowheads) are visible on the buccal mucosa.

Koplik spots are pathognomonic for measles infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic nicotine abuse (e.g., smoking, tobacco chewing) can cause white patches in the oral mucosa (leukoplakia) due to carcinoma in situ. However, these patches cannot be scraped off, typically occur on the buccal mucosa, gingiva, lower lip, or floor of the mouth (unlike the predominantly palatal lesions in this patient), and are usually not associated with odynophagia.
Image Description:

Poorly demarcated, white plaque on the buccal mucosa that cannot be scraped off.

This finding is most consistent with oral leukoplakia, which may develop into squamous cell carcinoma.

E) INCORRECT:

EBV can cause white patches in the oral mucosa (oral hairy leukoplakia) in immunocompromised patients. But these patches cannot be scraped off, typically occur on the sides of the tongue (unlike the predominantly palatal lesions in this patient), and are usually not associated with odynophagia. EBV can also cause acute tonsillitis (infectious mononucleosis), which would present with odynophagia and possibly white patches (exudates) that can be scraped off. However, the location of the patches on the palate and uvula instead of the tonsils, and the absence of other features of acute tonsillitis or infectious mononucleosis (e.g., fever, enlarged red tonsils, cervical lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly) indicate a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

A 3–5 cm confluent, white plaque with a hairy appearance is seen across the left lateral side of the tongue that, in this case, could not be scraped off using a spatula.

This clinical finding is characteristic of oral hairy leukoplakia.

F) INCORRECT:

Group A streptococcus can cause acute tonsillitis, which would present with odynophagia and possibly white patches (exudates) that can be scraped off. However, the location of the patches on the palate and uvula instead of the tonsils, and the absence of features of tonsillitis (e.g., fever, enlarged inflamed tonsils, tender cervical lymphadenopathy) indicate a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

The tonsils are bilaterally enlarged and gray-white exudates are visible at the openings of the tonsillar crypts as well as on the posterior aspect of the tongue. The soft palate, anterior tonsillar pillars, and the uvula are erythematous and edematous.

Tonsillar inflammation and exudates are characteristic features of acute bacterial tonsillitis, which is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (group A Beta-hemolytic streptococcus).
questions.hint: Curdy, white oral patches that can be easily scraped off suggest oral thrush.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician because of worsening pain with swallowing for 3 days and a dry sensation in the mouth over the past week. She has a history of asthma controlled with inhaled fluticasone and albuterol. Physical examination shows white plaques on the dorsal surface of the tongue and buccal mucosa that bleed when scraped off. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Triamcinolone is used to treat recurrent aphthous stomatitis. This condition typically manifests with lesions on nonkeratinized areas of the mouth (e.g., soft palate and inner cheeks) rather than keratinized areas such as the dorsal surface of the tongue. Triamcinolone has no role in the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis, which this patient likely has.

B) CORRECT:

Topical antifungal drugs such as nystatin oral suspension and clotrimazole troches are first-line therapies for oropharyngeal candidiasis, which this patient likely developed due to chronic local immunosuppression from prolonged use of inhaled steroids (e.g., fluticasone). Nystatin binds to ergosterols in the fungal cell membrane and forms pores that disrupt electrolyte balance. It is too toxic for systemic use but has minimal oral bioavailability and is thus safe for treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis.

Additional risk factors for developing oropharyngeal candidiasis include immunosuppressive conditions (e.g., HIV infection, diabetes mellitus), use of dentures, xerostomia, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy.
Image Description:

Yellow-white cottage cheese-like plaques are visible on the inflamed oropharyngeal mucosa.

These white plaques are pathognomonic of oral candidiasis (oral thrush), an opportunistic infection caused by Candida albicans.

C) INCORRECT:

Penicillin G is used to treat various bacterial infections such as acute tonsillitis caused by Streptococcus pyogenes. This condition classically manifests with painful swallowing, as seen in this patient, but also causes tonsillar exudates and tender lymphadenopathy, which are not seen here. Penicillin G has no role in the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis, which this patient likely has.

D) INCORRECT:

Valganciclovir is an antiviral medication that is used to treat cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. CMV esophagitis typically manifests with painful swallowing but also causes linear mucosal ulcers, which are not seen here. Valganciclovir has no role in the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis, which this patient likely has.

E) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is used to treat herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections and varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infections. Herpetic gingivostomatitis is an HSV infection that typically manifests with painful swallowing but also causes erythema and painful ulcerations on perioral skin and the oral mucosa, which are not seen here. Acyclovir has no role in the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis, which this patient likely has.

F) INCORRECT:

Griseofulvin is an oral antifungal used to treat tinea infections (e.g., tinea pedis). Griseofulvin has no role in the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis, which this patient likely has.

G) INCORRECT:

Amphotericin B can be used to treat severe systemic fungal infections (e.g., invasive candidiasis), fungal meningitis, and fungal cystitis. Amphotericin B has no role in the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis, which this patient likely has.
questions.hint: This woman has oropharyngeal candidiasis (oral thrush), an infection caused by Candida albicans that manifests with painful swallowing, a dry sensation in the mouth, and white plaques on the oral mucosa that can be scraped off.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of redness and swelling of the head of his penis for the past 2 days. The mother says that he has constantly been scratching his genital area since yesterday. She has also noticed an unpleasant smell when changing his diaper. One week ago, the boy had a diaper rash that slightly improved with an over-the-counter ointment. He is uncircumcised and has no history of serious illness. The boy's parents, as well as his two older sisters, are well. Immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 75th percentile for height and 60th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the genital area shows erythematous plaques and scattered pustules in the perianal area, inguinal creases, and on the glans penis and foreskin as well as edema of the glans penis. A white, curd-like discharge appears from under the foreskin. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. In addition to counseling on proper genital hygiene, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

White curd-like discharge from under the foreskin, the presence of scattered satellite pustules, the involvement of skin folds (inguinal creases), and persistent diaper dermatitis (> 3 days) strongly suggest fungal balanoposthitis as a result of candidal superinfection of diaper dermatitis. In infants, fungal balanoposthitis in association with candida diaper dermatitis is usually a clinical diagnosis and empiric topical antifungal agents (e.g., clotrimazole) are indicated to treat this local mucocutaneous dermatophyte infection. In addition, barrier ointments should be applied 2–3 times daily until resolution is achieved. Further measures to control the local inflammation include sitz baths and avoidance of irritants (e.g., soap, talc powder), as well as counseling on genital hygiene.

In prepubertal patients that have balanoposthitis with urethral discharge, diagnostic workup for sexually transmitted infections (STIs) is indicated and, if STIs are confirmed, evaluation for sexual abuse should follow.
Image Description:

There is diffuse dark erythema with confluent papules, scaling, and satellite lesions of the perianal and infraumbilical region. Skin folds are involved.

These findings suggest Candida diaper dermatitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin is indicated in the case of bacterial balanoposthitis due to group A Streptococci (GAS). Patients with GAS balanoposthitis typically have a history of recent or ongoing GAS infection (e.g., tonsillopharyngitis, perianal streptococcal dermatitis) or contact with an infected individual (e.g., family member). Perianal streptococcal dermatitis typically manifests with bright red erythema most prominent in the perianal area, rather than with widespread pustules and plaques extending to the inguinal creases. Satellite pustules and a curd-like discharge from under the foreskin suggest a different etiology of balanoposthitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral acyclovir is indicated in genital herpes simplex virus infection, which can cause balanoposthitis. Genital herpes is classically associated with painful and pruritic vesicles in the anogenital region, rather than plaques and satellite pustules. Moreover, a white curd-like discharge would not be expected. Genital herpes is uncommon in toddlers and would warrant evaluation for sexual abuse.

D) INCORRECT:

Circumcision (or alternatively preputioplasty) is a treatment option for patients with balanoposthitis that is recurrent or fails conservative treatment because the foreskin predisposes to future infections. This patient has neither of these indications, so another step in management is more appropriate at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical hydrocortisone can be used in the treatment of irritant balanoposthitis. The presence of satellite pustules and white curd-like discharge from under the foreskin strongly suggest a different, infectious cause of balanoposthitis, for which topical corticosteroids are contraindicated.
questions.hint: Erythema and edema of both the glans penis and the foreskin indicate balanoposthitis. This patient's history of a pruritic malodorous diaper rash (diaper dermatitis) for one week and the white curd-like discharge suggest a specific etiology.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, comes to the physician because of a 6-day history of progressively worsening pain and itching in both breasts. She describes the pain as “stabbing” and reports that it begins in her nipples, radiates to the chest, and is worsened by breastfeeding. Fifteen days ago, she gave birth to a healthy 3600-g (7-lb 15-oz) newborn at term via vaginal delivery. She did not receive regular antenatal care and delivery was uncomplicated. Vital signs for mother and child are normal. The newborn is at the 50th percentile for length and 45th percentile for weight. Examination of the breasts shows mild flaking around the nipple-areolar complex without erythema, fissuring, or tenderness. Examination of the newborn shows a white coating on the tongue that is easily scraped off. In both the mother and newborn, the remainder of the examination discloses no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Systemic antifungal therapy for the mother along with formula feeding until the newborn's oral lesions resolve
Systemic antifungal therapy for mother and newborn along with continued breastfeeding
Topical antifungal therapy for mother and newborn along with continued breastfeeding
Topical antifungal therapy for the newborn along with formula feeding until the results of HIV testing and breast milk culture are obtained

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mother and newborn should be treated simultaneously with antifungal therapy to avoid persistent infection. Additionally, breastfeeding should be continued during therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Systemic antifungal therapy is only indicated in patients who do not improve with first-line treatment, in those with systemic candidiasis, and/or in immunocompromised individuals.

C) CORRECT:

Topical antifungal therapy (e.g., nystatin, miconazole) is indicated in patients with noninvasive mucocutaneous candidiasis (e.g., neonatal oral thrush, mammary candidiasis). In the case of mammary candidiasis, simultaneous treatment of mother and infant is necessary to prevent a persistent infection. Additionally, all material that comes in contact with the breasts, breast milk, or the infant's mouth should be washed and/or sterilized. Breastfeeding should be continued during therapy. However, infected breast milk should not be frozen because it contains spores. Systemic antifungal therapy is only indicated in patients who do not improve with topical therapy, in those with systemic candidiasis (e.g., candidemia, organ infiltration), and/or in immunocompromised individuals.

Empirical treatment is recommended in patients with suspected noninvasive mucocutaneous candidiasis. Although topical nystatin is the first-line treatment in newborns with oral candidiasis, topical miconazole is preferred in areas where the resistance of Candida albicans to nystatin is high.

D) INCORRECT:

Mother and newborn should be treated simultaneously with antifungal therapy to avoid persistent infection. Moreover, breastfeeding should be continued. Because lactoferrin can inhibit the growth of Candida albicans, a breast milk culture is not routinely recommended, and patients are treated empirically. Finally, testing for immunosuppression (e.g., HIV testing) is not routinely recommended in patients with candidal infection.
questions.hint: In a newborn, white oral lesions that can be scraped off suggest neonatal oral thrush. This feature together with stabbing breast pain that is more severe than would be expected from examination findings and worsens with breastfeeding is characteristic of mammary candidiasis.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman reports a 3-day history of mouth soreness without retrosternal pain or odynophagia. She uses a daily inhaled glucocorticoid for mild persistent asthma. In addition, she took a course of antibiotics one week ago for a urinary tract infection.
On examination, she has nonadherent white plaques on the posterior aspect of her tongue. Testing for HIV infection is negative.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The presence of nonadherent white plaques on the buccal mucosa, palate, or tongue indicates oropharyngeal candidiasis. Risk factors include immunosuppression, inhaled glucocorticoid use, and recent antibiotic use.

First-line therapy for mild oropharyngeal candidiasis is clotrimazole troches or miconazole mucoadhesive buccal tablets. Nystatin suspension or pastilles are alternative choices. For more severe disease or if there is no response to local therapy, oral fluconazole is recommended. This agent can also be used as first-line therapy for esophageal candidiasis, which would manifest with odynophagia or retrosternal pain. Itraconazole is usually reserved for fluconazole-refractory candidiasis.

Key learning point: First-line therapy for oropharyngeal candidiasis is clotrimazole troches or miconazole mucoadhesive buccal tablets.

B) INCORRECT:

For more severe disease or if there is no response to local therapy, oral fluconazole is recommended. This agent can also be used as first-line therapy for esophageal candidiasis, which would manifest with odynophagia or retrosternal pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Itraconazole is usually reserved for fluconazole-refractory candidiasis.

D) INCORRECT:

Itraconazole is usually reserved for fluconazole-refractory candidiasis.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical glucocorticoids are first-line treatments for patients with symptomatic oral lichen planus, which can cause adherent white plaques and can be confused with candidiasis. Topical glucocorticoids worsen oral candidiasis.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man presents with fever and dyspnea that has progressed during the past week. He has a history of injection-drug use.
On examination, his temperature is 39.1°C. He has a diastolic murmur and crackles in both lung fields. He has track marks in his antecubital fossae and groin.
A chest radiograph reveals pulmonary edema.
A transthoracic echocardiogram reveals aortic insufficiency and a 1.5-cm mobile vegetation on the aortic valve. Blood cultures from admission become positive within 48 hours; Gram stain demonstrates large gram-positive organisms with pseudohyphae.
In addition to surgical intervention, which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin has no activity against Candida.

B) INCORRECT:

Gentamicin has no activity against Candida.

C) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone has no activity against Candida.

D) INCORRECT:

Fluconazole is often used for suppressive therapy after combined medical and surgical intervention; it is only appropriate after a fluconazole-resistant species of Candida is ruled out.

E) CORRECT:

Injection-drug use is a risk factor for the development of native-valve infectious endocarditis. Most cases of infectious endocarditis that occur in people who inject drugs are caused by Staphylococcus aureus, but these people are also at risk for infection with unusual pathogens, including gram-negative bacilli and fungi, particularly Candida. Candida albicans grows on routine blood cultures, appearing as large gram-positive organisms with pseudohyphae. S. aureus are also gram-positive cocci but are smaller and do not produce pseudohyphae. The tricuspid valve is often affected in people who inject drugs, but infection can affect any valve. Blood cultures positive for yeast within 48 hours in the setting of an aortic vegetation suggests infectious endocarditis due to Candida spp.

Given the high mortality rates associated with fungal endocarditis, amphotericin, which is a fungicidal agent, is the preferred initial antimicrobial agent. Addition of flucytosine may be beneficial. Fungal endocarditis is also an indication for surgical intervention.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment regimen for a patient with infective endocarditis due to Candida spp. consists of amphotericin in addition to surgical management.

questions.text:
An 89-year-old woman undergoes emergency exploratory laparotomy for diverticulitis that is complicated by perforation. She is subsequently admitted to the intensive care unit, where her course is complicated by hyperglycemia from known type 2 diabetes, postoperative ileus requiring parenteral nutrition, respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation, and ventilator-associated pneumonia. She is also treated with fluconazole for 7 days because yeast was found in her urine culture; yeast was also found in several tracheal aspirates and in a stool specimen.
On postoperative day 15, despite receiving ceftriaxone and metronidazole, the patient develops fever and severe hypotension that is unresponsive to intravenous fluids. On examination, she is clammy, her central-line insertion site is clean, and her abdomen is soft with a well-healing incision. Testing for Clostridioides difficile infection is negative. The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
In addition to empiric treatment with vancomycin and meropenem, which one of the following agents is most appropriate for this patient to receive while awaiting results of blood cultures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole does not add anaerobic activity to meropenem.

B) INCORRECT:

Levofloxacin may provide additional gram-negative coverage for Pseudomonas (depending on local susceptibility patterns) but does not cover Candida, the most likely pathogen.

C) INCORRECT:

Fluconazole is a reasonable option for treatment of candidemia in patients who are not critically ill and have not received the drug recently; susceptibility testing is warranted to confirm that the Candida isolate is sensitive to the drug.

D) INCORRECT:

Amphotericin B deoxycholate is not recommended as first-line therapy for suspected candidemia because of its potential nephrotoxicity and the availability of safer, efficacious agents.

E) CORRECT:

Candidemia should be suspected in a patient who develops sepsis or septic shock after abdominal surgery or who has other pertinent risk factors (colonization at other sites, prior use of broad-spectrum antibiotics, previous abdominal surgery, hemodialysis, central venous catheters, or parenteral nutrition). Management in this case should consist of intensification of antibiotic therapy and provision of supportive care for septic shock. Although antifungals might be deferred while the results of blood cultures are pending, this patient is extremely sick and has multiple risk factors for candidemia. In that setting, empiric therapy for candidemia is reasonable. An echinocandin (anidulafungin, caspofungin, or micafungin) is most appropriate for patients with severe illness and for patients with prior use of fluconazole, which increases the risk for azole-resistant Candida infections, such as Candida glabrata.

Key learning point: The type of antifungal agent that is most appropriate to include in a regimen for treating severe candidemia is an echinocandin (anidulafungin, caspofungin, or micafungin).

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man who receives infliximab for treatment of severe psoriasis reports a one-week history of drainage from and increasing tenderness around his implanted port reservoir.
He is afebrile and appears well. There is a 2-cm by 2-cm area of erythema and induration over the subcutaneous pocket overlying the port. There is also tenderness and a small amount of seropurulent discharge with light palpation.
Cultures of the discharge are obtained, as are blood cultures. Gram stain of the discharge shows numerous pseudohyphae. Twelve hours after collection, both sets of blood cultures are growing yeast.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Remove the port and drain the abscess; additional antimicrobial therapy is not necessary
Retain the port and treat with intravenous antifungal therapy for 4 to 6 weeks
Remove the port, drain the abscess, and treat with intravenous antifungal therapy for 5 to 7 days
Retain the port and treat with intravenous antifungal therapy and topical ketoconazole cream for 21 days
Remove the port, drain the abscess, and start intravenous antifungal therapy; obtain serial blood cultures, and continue treatment until 14 days after the first negative culture

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In addition to having the port or catheter removed, all patients with candidemia should receive antifungal therapy for 14 days from the time of negative blood cultures and resolution of clinical signs and symptoms of candidal infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravascular catheters, including implanted subcutaneous port reservoirs, should be removed in cases of catheter-related bloodstream infection due to Candida species.

C) INCORRECT:

In addition to having the port or catheter removed, all patients with candidemia should receive antifungal therapy for 14 days from the time of negative blood cultures and resolution of clinical signs and symptoms of candidal infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravascular catheters, including implanted subcutaneous port reservoirs, should be removed in cases of catheter-related bloodstream infection due to Candida species.

E) CORRECT:

Intravascular catheters, including implanted subcutaneous port reservoirs, should be removed in cases of catheter-related bloodstream infection due to Candida species. If an abscess is evident at the exit site (or in the pocket of a port), debridement and drainage of the abscess is also required.

In addition to having the port or catheter removed, all patients with candidemia should receive antifungal therapy for 14 days from the time of negative blood cultures and resolution of clinical signs and symptoms of candidal infection.

Key learning point: The recommended treatment regimen for a patient with a port abscess and concomitant fungemia is removal of the port, incision and drainage of the abscess, and antifungal therapy for at least 14 days after the first negative blood culture.

questions.text:
An 8-month-old boy is evaluated for a rash in his diaper area that has been worsening for the past 7 days.
Examination reveals a prominent, bright-red, well-demarcated, slightly scaly rash involving the buttocks, genitals, inguinal folds, lower abdomen, and thighs. The periphery is marked by slightly scaly papules and pustules (figure).
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in managing this child’s rash?

choices.text: Recommend a topical barrier cream alone
Recommend a topical ointment containing bacitracin-neomycin-polymyxin B

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Barrier creams are important and should be used in conjunction with a topical antifungal for the treatment of candidal dermatitis in order to protect the skin from irritation. Barrier creams alone, however, will not treat the underlying candidal infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Low-potency topical glucocorticoids, such as 1% hydrocortisone ointment, are often used in conjunction with antifungal creams if there is very severe underlying inflammation that is impeding the healing of the rash. However, glucocorticoids should not be used as the sole treatment, and superpotent topical glucocorticoids, such as clobetasol, should be avoided in the diaper area. Combination high-potency topical glucocorticoids mixed with a topical antifungal are also not recommended for use in the diaper area because of possible adverse effects from the high-potency topical glucocorticoid.

C) INCORRECT:

Antibacterial agents, such as mupirocin and bacitracin-neomycin-polymyxin B, are not effective against fungi, including Candida species, and have no role in the treatment of candidal diaper rash.

D) INCORRECT:

Antibacterial agents, such as mupirocin and bacitracin-neomycin-polymyxin B, are not effective against fungi, including Candida species, and have no role in the treatment of candidal diaper rash.

E) CORRECT:

Diaper dermatitis is a common condition in which the skin under the diaper becomes red. Classic (irritant) diaper dermatitis is multifactorial but is caused primarily by prolonged contact of the skin with moisture in the diaper from urine, digestive enzymes, and bile salts. It is characterized by a dry, erythematous rash that spares the creases of the thighs and folds of the skin because the irritating moisture mixture is unable to get to the skin protected by these creases and folds. In contrast, candidal diaper dermatitis, as in this case, tends to involve the inguinal folds and to feature discrete inflammatory papules and pustules (so-called satellite lesions).

Candidal diaper dermatitis is a fungal infection most commonly caused by Candida albicans, which thrives in warm, moist environments. Candidal dermatitis typically develops as a superinfection 3 to 4 days after the onset of irritant diaper dermatitis. The gold standard for diagnosis is the appearance of budding yeast with pseudohyphae on potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation; however, in primary care settings, the diagnosis is often made clinically.

The first-line treatment for isolated candidal diaper dermatitis is a topical antifungal agent, such as nystatin or clotrimazole.

Key learning point: The appropriate treatment for candidal diaper dermatitis is a topical antifungal agent, such as nystatin.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the office because of worsening pain with swallowing for 3 days and a dry sensation in the mouth over the past week. She has a history of asthma controlled with inhaled fluticasone and albuterol. Physical examination shows white plaques on the dorsal surface of the tongue and buccal mucosa that bleed when scraped off. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Topical antifungal drugs such as nystatin oral suspension and clotrimazole troches are first-line therapies for oropharyngeal candidiasis, which this patient likely developed due to chronic local immunosuppression from prolonged use of inhaled steroids (e.g., fluticasone). Nystatin binds to ergosterols in the fungal cell membrane and forms pores that disrupt electrolyte balance. It is too toxic for systemic use but has minimal oral bioavailability and is thus safe for treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis.

Additional risk factors for developing oropharyngeal candidiasis include immunosuppressive conditions (e.g., HIV infection, diabetes mellitus), use of dentures, xerostomia, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy.
Image Description:

Yellow-white cottage cheese-like plaques are visible on the inflamed oropharyngeal mucosa.

These white plaques are pathognomonic of oral candidiasis (oral thrush), an opportunistic infection caused by Candida albicans.

B) INCORRECT:

Penicillin G is used to treat various bacterial infections such as acute tonsillitis caused by Streptococcus pyogenes. This condition classically manifests with painful swallowing, as seen in this patient, but also causes tonsillar exudates and tender lymphadenopathy, which are not seen here. Penicillin G has no role in the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis, which this patient likely has.

C) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is used to treat herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections and varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infections. Herpetic gingivostomatitis is an HSV infection that typically manifests with painful swallowing but also causes erythema and painful ulcerations on perioral skin and the oral mucosa, which are not seen here. Acyclovir has no role in the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis, which this patient likely has.

D) INCORRECT:

Griseofulvin is an oral antifungal used to treat tinea infections (e.g., tinea pedis). Griseofulvin has no role in the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis, which this patient likely has.

E) INCORRECT:

Amphotericin B is used to treat severe systemic fungal infections (e.g., invasive candidiasis), fungal meningitis, and fungal cystitis. Amphotericin B has no role in the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis, which this patient likely has.
questions.hint: This woman has oropharyngeal candidiasis (oral thrush), an infection caused by Candida albicans that manifests with painful swallowing, a dry sensation in the mouth, and white plaques on the oral mucosa that can be scraped off.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes to the office because of white lesions in his mouth for 4 days. He also has pain while chewing food. He was diagnosed with non-Hodgkin lymphoma around 8 months ago. He is undergoing chemotherapy and is currently on his fourth cycle. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy is present. Oral examination shows white plaques on his tongue and buccal mucosa that bleed when scraped off with gauze. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Systemic fluconazole therapy can be used to treat patients with moderate to severe oropharyngeal candidiasis. However, oral rather than intravenous fluconazole is recommended for these patients. Intravenous fluconazole therapy is usually reserved for patients with esophageal candidiasis who cannot tolerate oral therapy or patients with systemic candidiasis.

B) INCORRECT:

Although culture of the lesions can be performed to diagnose oropharyngeal candidiasis, it is only used in recurrent or refractory disease to determine possible resistances as results usually take time. This is the patient's first episode of oral thrush and there are no indicators of unusual or resistant Candida species.

C) CORRECT:

Topical antifungal therapy (e.g., troches, mucoadhesive buccal tablets, pastilles) is considered first-line for most patients with oropharyngeal candidiasis. Preferred topical agents include clotrimazole, miconazole, and nystatin. Oral fluconazole is also used, most commonly in patients with moderate to severe symptoms.

The diagnosis of oropharyngeal candidiasis is most often clinical. KOH test and/or tissue culture are usually reserved for patients with inconclusive clinical findings. HIV testing should be performed in patients with no identifiable risk factors for oropharyngeal candidiasis.
Image Description:

Yellow-white cottage cheese-like plaques are visible on the inflamed oropharyngeal mucosa.

These white plaques are pathognomonic of oral candidiasis (oral thrush), an opportunistic infection caused by Candida albicans.

D) INCORRECT:

A biopsy of the lesion would be indicated in the case of suspected oral leukoplakia, a precancerous lesion, in which malignancy should be ruled out. While the white lesions of leukoplakia resemble oropharyngeal candidiasis and are common in tobacco users, they are usually asymptomatic and cannot be scraped off.
Image Description:

Poorly demarcated, white plaque on the buccal mucosa that cannot be scraped off.

This finding is most consistent with oral leukoplakia, which may develop into squamous cell carcinoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical corticosteroids are used in the treatment of severe aphthous stomatitis, a disease that manifests with painful oral ulcers covered by a yellow fibrinous pseudomembrane. White plaques that can be scraped off are not typical of the disease, making oral candidiasis more likely.
Image Description:

Two shallow spherical ulcers are visible on the buccal mucosa of the lower lip. The borders of the ulcer are erythematous and well defined. Healthy granulation tissue is visible on the floor of the ulcers.

These aphthous ulcers are typically painful and resolve spontaneously without scarring. Aphthous stomatitis is a condition characterized by recurrent episodes of aphthous ulcer formation.
questions.hint: White plaques on the oral mucosa that can be scraped off are suggestive of oropharyngeal candidiasis. Further common findings include pain when eating, loss of taste, and a cottony feeling in the mouth. Candida albicans infections most commonly affect immunocompromised individuals, e.g., patients with hematologic malignancies.

questions.text: Four days after undergoing liver transplantation, a 47-year-old man develops fever, chills, malaise, and confusion while in the intensive care unit. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F). Blood cultures grow an organism. Microscopic examination of this organism after incubation at 25°C (77°F) for 3 hours is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aspergillus fumigatus may cause invasive infections in immunosuppressed patients and would appear as septate hyphae with acute-angle branching. However, since Aspergillus is a monomorphic fungus that only has a mold (hyphal) form, yeast cells would not be expected. Moreover, the hyphal elements of Aspergillus do not have constrictions at the septa. Instead, a specialized bulbous vesicle with a row of sprouting spores would be present at the end of hyphae. Finally, patients with invasive aspergillosis would typically have symptoms of acute necrotizing pneumonia (e.g., hemoptysis).
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Aspergillus fumigatus

Several buds are visible sprouting from the thread-like structure of the septate hyphae (green overlays). Buds are composed of a stalk (conidiophore; blue overlay) topped by a conidial head. The head consists of a central spherical vesicle (not visible here but indicated by yellow circle) surrounded by chains of prophialide (examples indicated by red arrowheads) and phialide projections (examples indicated by green arrowheads) with conidia tips (examples indicated by black arrowheads). The base is formed by a foot cell (red overlay).

B) CORRECT:

Candida albicans is a dimorphic fungus that appears as budding yeast cells with pseudohyphae at 20–25°C and forms germ tubes at 37°C. The formation of germ tubes can be used to differentiate C. albicans from other species of Candida as well as other yeasts. C. albicans typically causes mucocutaneous infections (e.g., oral thrush) but can result in disseminated hematogenous infection with clinical features of sepsis (e.g., fever, chills, malaise, confusion) in severely immunocompromised patients. Treatment of systemic infection consists of fluconazole, echinocandins, or amphotericin B.

C) INCORRECT:

Cryptococcus neoformans usually causes meningitis or encephalitis in severely immunocompromised patients (e.g., from HIV infection). Meningitis can manifest with fever, chills, malaise, and confusion. However, other symptoms, such as headache and neck stiffness, would also be expected. Furthermore, on microscopic examination, C. neoformans would appear as an encapsulated yeast without hyphae or pseudohyphae.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture

Numerous spherical yeast cells of different sizes are visible, with the polysaccharide capsules appearing in darker blue.

D) INCORRECT:

Immunosuppressed patients are at increased risk of infection by Mucor spp. (e.g., Mucor racemosus), which would grow rapidly at 25°C and appear as broad, branching hyphae. However, the hyphae would be aseptate and branch at 90° or obtuse angles unlike the septate hyphae with acute-angle branching seen here. Also, Mucor is a monomorphic fungus that only has a mold (hyphal) form; yeast cells would not be expected. Moreover, mucormycosis typically presents with features of fulminant destructive rhinosinusitis (e.g., headache, facial pain, black nasal discharge).
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of stomach tissue (H&E stain; 975x magnification)

A broad, nonseptate hypha can be seen branching into two hyphae at a wide angle of ∼ 90°.

Aseptate hyphae with unusually wide branching angles are characteristic features of mucormycosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Microscopic examination of Malassezia furfur would show round yeast-like cells and septated hyphal elements. However, the hyphal elements of M. furfur would be short, curved, and unbranched (“spaghetti-and-meatball” appearance), and M. furfur only grows in a narrow temperature range of 32–35°C. Moreover, M. furfur causes a superficial skin infection characterized by hypopigmented macules on the trunk (pityriasis versicolor). It typically does not cause a disseminated hematogenous infection.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a skin scraping

Throughout the image, there are multiple short, septated hyphae (filamentous structures) and spherical spores. These different morphological forms are responsible for the “spaghetti and meatballs” pattern (hyphae being the spaghetti and yeast being the meatballs), which is a typical finding of Malassezia furfur.
questions.hint: This patient who recently underwent liver transplantation is most likely on immunosuppressive therapy. The image shows multiple oval yeast cells with branching, septate hyphal elements. However, the presence of constrictions at the septa indicates that these are not true septate hyphae but rather pseudohyphae formed by the budding of yeast cells.

questions.text: A 4-month-old boy is brought to the office by his father because of a progressively worsening rash on his buttocks for the last week. He cries during diaper changes and is more fussy than usual. Physical examination of the boy shows erythematous papules and plaques in the bilateral inguinal creases, on the scrotum, and in the gluteal cleft. Small areas of maceration are also present. A diagnosis is made, and treatment with topical clotrimazole is initiated. Microscopic examination of skin scrapings from this patient's rash is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Fruiting bodies with septate, acute-angle hyphae
Round yeast surrounded by budding yeast cells

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Narrow budding, encapsulated yeast on India ink staining indicates Cryptococcus neoformans infection. Cryptococcus neoformans infection is primarily seen in immunocompromised patients and can cause pneumonia, cryptococcal meningoencephalitis, and brain abscesses. Cryptococcus neoformans is not associated with diaper rash.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (India ink stain)

Numerous spherical yeast cells of different sizes can be seen. The polysaccharide capsules appear as yellowish halos around the cell walls (dark circles).

These features are characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans under light microscopy.

B) CORRECT:

Candida albicans appears as oval, budding yeast with pseudohyphae in skin scrapings of an infection. Candida albicans is part of the normal skin flora, but infection can occur when there is an imbalance that allows local Candida albicans overgrowth. Infants are often affected by Candida mucocutaneous infections in the anogenital region since overgrowth is facilitated by the prolonged damp and warm conditions of a diaper.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (200x magnification)

A cluster of yeast-like cells (arrowhead) is visible in the upper right corner of the image. Arising from this cluster are numerous pseudohyphae identifiable as long filamentous nonseptate structures (example indicated by a blue overlay). Asexual budding spores (blastospores; example indicated by red overlay) arise along the sides of the pseudohyphae. Thick-walled solitary circular chlamydospores (resting stage of Candida; example indicated by green overlay) arise from the tips of the pseudohyphae.

This coexistence of different morphological types (yeast cells, pseudohyphae, budding blastospores, and resting chlamydospores) is typical of Candida albicans.

C) INCORRECT:

Fruiting bodies with septate, acute-angle hyphae (45°) on tissue biopsy indicate Aspergillus fumigatus infection. Aspergillus fumigatus can cause allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), chronic pulmonary aspergillosis, invasive aspergillosis, and infective endocarditis. Although Aspergillus fumigatus can cause irritation of the skin in patients with ABPA, it is not associated with diaper rash.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Aspergillus fumigatus

Several buds are visible sprouting from the thread-like structure of the septate hyphae (green overlays). Buds are composed of a stalk (conidiophore; blue overlay) topped by a conidial head. The head consists of a central spherical vesicle (not visible here but indicated by yellow circle) surrounded by chains of prophialide (examples indicated by red arrowheads) and phialide projections (examples indicated by green arrowheads) with conidia tips (examples indicated by black arrowheads). The base is formed by a foot cell (red overlay).

D) INCORRECT:

Round yeast surrounded by budding yeast cells (captain's wheel) on KOH test (potassium hydroxide smear) indicates Paracoccidioides brasiliensis infection. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis infection is most often asymptomatic, but it can manifest with acute pneumonia, painful nasopharyngeal ulcerations, and verrucous skin lesions. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis is not associated with diaper rash.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Paracoccidioides brasiliensis (methenamine silver stain)

A circular cell with round budding daughter cells can be seen in the center of the image. This appearance (“pilot's wheel”) is characteristic of Paracoccidioides species. Additional Paracoccidioides cells that do not have the classic appearance can be seen in the upper left.

E) INCORRECT:

Broad-based budding yeast on KOH test (potassium hydroxide smear) indicates Blastomyces dermatitidis infection. This patient has a diaper rash and no evidence of systemic disease (e.g., pneumonia, flulike symptoms), making a Blastomyces dermatitidis infection highly unlikely.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of skin tissue sample (GMS stain)

Thick-walled fungi with single broad-based buds are visible.

This is the typical appearance of Blastomyces dermatitidis in yeast form (at body temperature, 37°C). At room temperature (∼ 23°C ), this dimorphic fungus exists in mold form.
questions.hint: This patient has typical signs of a diaper rash due to Candida albicans. It can be treated with a variety of topical antifungal agents such as clotrimazole.

questions.text:
A 10-day-old infant is brought to the clinic by her mother due to difficulty feeding and fussiness. The mother mentions rarely sterilizing bottle nipples. The infant's weight is at the 10th percentile. Examination shows white patches on the tongue and inner cheeks that can be scraped off, leaving a reddened surface, and no skin rash.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral hairy leukoplakia is linked to Epstein-Barr virus in immunocompromised adults, not neonates. Lesions are adherent and corrugated, unlike the removable white plaques described. The infant's history and findings suggest local contamination, not oral hairy leukoplakia.

B) CORRECT:

Oral candidiasis is caused by Candida albicans, an opportunistic fungus that can overgrow in neonates due to immature immune defenses. Poorly sterilized bottle nipples can facilitate fungal colonization. The condition manifests with white plaques in the mouth that can be scraped off, revealing an erythematous base. This presentation indicates mucosal irritation and inflammation, leading to feeding difficulties and fussiness. The pathophysiology involves an imbalance in local microbial flora, where Candida thrives in moist environments with suboptimal hygiene.

Key learning point: Oral thrush in infants presents as white plaques on the oral mucosa that can be wiped off and is treated with antifungal agents like nystatin.
Image Description:

Lips, tongue, and oral cavity show thick, white-to-yellow plaques that can be easily scraped off with a spatula.

These findings indicate oral candidiasis, which occurs most commonly in immunocompromised patients.

C) INCORRECT:

Herpetic gingivostomatitis, caused by HSV-1, features painful vesicular lesions and gingival inflammation, often with fever. The infant's white plaques scrape off, indicating a fungal cause, not the vesicular or ulcerative lesions of herpetic infection. The infant's age and lack of systemic symptoms further reduce the likelihood of herpetic gingivostomatitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Geographic tongue presents with erythematous patches bordered by a white margin, typically on the dorsal tongue. Lesions are migratory and asymptomatic, rarely affecting feeding. The infant's lesions are white patches that scrape off, indicating an infectious process, unlike geographic tongue.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to your clinic with several weeks of difficulty swallowing. Examination of the oropharynx reveals lesions on the palate and tongue that can be easily scraped off. An image of the lesions is provided. Which one of the following is the strongest risk factor for these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

EBV can cause white patches in the oral mucosa (oral hairy leukoplakia) in immunocompromised patients. But these patches cannot be scraped off, typically occur on the sides of the tongue (unlike the predominantly palatal lesions in this patient), and are usually not associated with odynophagia. EBV can also cause acute tonsillitis (infectious mononucleosis), which would present with odynophagia and possibly white patches (exudates) that can be scraped off. However, the location of the patches on the palate and uvula instead of the tonsils, and the absence of other features of acute tonsillitis or infectious mononucleosis (e.g., fever, enlarged red tonsils, cervical lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly) indicate a different diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic nicotine abuse (e.g., smoking, tobacco chewing) can cause white patches in the oral mucosa (leukoplakia) due to carcinoma in situ. However, these patches cannot be scraped off, typically occur on the buccal mucosa, gingiva, lower lip, or floor of the mouth (unlike the predominantly palatal lesions in this patient), and are usually not associated with odynophagia.

C) INCORRECT:

Group A streptococcus can cause acute tonsillitis, which would present with odynophagia and possibly white patches (exudates) that can be scraped off. However, the location of the patches on the palate and uvula instead of the tonsils, and the absence of features of tonsillitis (e.g., fever, enlarged inflamed tonsils, tender cervical lymphadenopathy) indicate a different diagnosis.

D) CORRECT:

Oral thrush is caused by Candida albicans infection. The risk of mucocutaneous candidiasis is increased in patients with T-cell deficiency, which can occur in conditions such as HIV infection (↓ CD4+ T-cell count), severe combined immunodeficiency, and DiGeorge syndrome.
