Other risk factors for mucocutaneous candidiasis are uncontrolled diabetes mellitus, inhalation of corticosteroids, antibiotic use, and neonatal age group (Candida infection acquired during vaginal delivery). Mild oral thrush can be treated topically with nystatin (“swish and swallow”). The odynophagia seen in this patient could suggest involvement of the esophagus (candidal esophagitis). Severe thrush or candidal esophagitis will require systemic therapy with fluconazole or echinocandins.

Key learning point: Oral thrush is most strongly associated with T-cell deficiencies, such as decreased CD4+ T-cell counts seen in HIV infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Inhalation of corticosteroids (e.g., fluticasone in asthmatic patients) is a risk factor for oral thrush. Inhalation of salbutamol, a beta-2 agonist, is not a risk factor.
questions.hint: Curdy, white oral patches that can be easily scraped off suggest oral thrush.

questions.text: You are seeing a 4-month-old boy brought to your clinic by his father because of a progressively worsening rash on his buttocks over the past week. The father reports that the infant cries during diaper changes and is more fussy than usual. On examination, there are erythematous papules and plaques in the bilateral inguinal creases, on the scrotum, and in the gluteal cleft, with small areas of maceration. You diagnose the condition and start treatment with topical clotrimazole. Microscopic examination of skin scrapings from this rash is most likely to show which one of the following findings?

choices.text: Fruiting bodies with septate, acute-angle hyphae.
Round yeast surrounded by budding yeast cells.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fruiting bodies with septate, acute-angle hyphae (45°) on tissue biopsy indicate Aspergillus fumigatus infection. Aspergillus fumigatus can cause allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), chronic pulmonary aspergillosis, invasive aspergillosis, and infective endocarditis. Although Aspergillus fumigatus can cause irritation of the skin in patients with ABPA, it is not associated with diaper rash.

B) INCORRECT:

Broad-based budding yeast on KOH test (potassium hydroxide smear) indicates Blastomyces dermatitidis infection. This patient has a diaper rash and no evidence of systemic disease (e.g., pneumonia, flulike symptoms), making a Blastomyces dermatitidis infection highly unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Narrow budding, encapsulated yeast on India ink staining indicates Cryptococcus neoformans infection. Cryptococcus neoformans infection is primarily seen in immunocompromised patients and can cause pneumonia, cryptococcal meningoencephalitis, and brain abscesses. Cryptococcus neoformans is not associated with diaper rash.

D) INCORRECT:

Round yeast surrounded by budding yeast cells (captain's wheel) on KOH test (potassium hydroxide smear) indicates Paracoccidioides brasiliensis infection. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis infection is most often asymptomatic, but it can manifest with acute pneumonia, painful nasopharyngeal ulcerations, and verrucous skin lesions. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis is not associated with diaper rash.

E) CORRECT:

Candida albicans appears as oval, budding yeast with pseudohyphae in skin scrapings of an infection. Candida albicans is part of the normal skin flora, but infection can occur when there is an imbalance that allows local Candida albicans overgrowth. Infants are often affected by Candida mucocutaneous infections in the anogenital region since overgrowth is facilitated by the prolonged damp and warm conditions of a diaper.

Key learning point: Candida albicans diaper rash is characterized microscopically by oval, budding yeast with pseudohyphae on skin scrapings.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (200x magnification)

A cluster of yeast-like cells (arrowhead) is visible in the upper right corner of the image. Arising from this cluster are numerous pseudohyphae identifiable as long filamentous nonseptate structures (example indicated by a blue overlay). Asexual budding spores (blastospores; example indicated by red overlay) arise along the sides of the pseudohyphae. Thick-walled solitary circular chlamydospores (resting stage of Candida; example indicated by green overlay) arise from the tips of the pseudohyphae.

This coexistence of different morphological types (yeast cells, pseudohyphae, budding blastospores, and resting chlamydospores) is typical of Candida albicans.
questions.hint: This patient has typical signs of a diaper rash due to Candida albicans. It can be treated with a variety of topical antifungal agents such as clotrimazole.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-day history of worsening pain with swallowing and a dry sensation in her mouth for the past week. She has a history of asthma managed with inhaled fluticasone and albuterol. On examination, there are white plaques on the dorsal surface of her tongue and buccal mucosa that bleed when scraped off. Which one of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is used to treat herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections and varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infections. Herpetic gingivostomatitis is an HSV infection that typically manifests with painful swallowing but also causes erythema and painful ulcerations on perioral skin and the oral mucosa, which are not seen here. Acyclovir has no role in the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis, which this patient likely has.

B) INCORRECT:

Penicillin G is used to treat various bacterial infections such as acute tonsillitis caused by Streptococcus pyogenes. This condition classically manifests with painful swallowing, as seen in this patient, but also causes tonsillar exudates and tender lymphadenopathy, which are not seen here. Penicillin G has no role in the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis, which this patient likely has.

C) INCORRECT:

Griseofulvin is an oral antifungal used to treat tinea infections (e.g., tinea pedis). Griseofulvin has no role in the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis, which this patient likely has.

D) CORRECT:

Topical antifungal drugs such as nystatin oral suspension and clotrimazole troches are first-line therapies for oropharyngeal candidiasis, which this patient likely developed due to chronic local immunosuppression from prolonged use of inhaled steroids (e.g., fluticasone). Nystatin binds to ergosterols in the fungal cell membrane and forms pores that disrupt electrolyte balance. It is too toxic for systemic use but has minimal oral bioavailability and is thus safe for treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis.

Additional risk factors for developing oropharyngeal candidiasis include immunosuppressive conditions (e.g., HIV infection, diabetes mellitus), use of dentures, xerostomia, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy.

Key learning point: Topical antifungals such as nystatin are first-line therapy for oropharyngeal candidiasis, especially in patients using inhaled corticosteroids.
Image Description:

Yellow-white cottage cheese-like plaques are visible on the inflamed oropharyngeal mucosa.

These white plaques are pathognomonic of oral candidiasis (oral thrush), an opportunistic infection caused by Candida albicans.

E) INCORRECT:

Amphotericin B is used to treat severe systemic fungal infections (e.g., invasive candidiasis), fungal meningitis, and fungal cystitis. Amphotericin B is not the first-line treatment for mild oropharyngeal candidiasis, which this patient likely has.
questions.hint: This woman has oropharyngeal candidiasis (oral thrush), an infection caused by Candida albicans that manifests with painful swallowing, a dry sensation in the mouth, and white plaques on the oral mucosa that can be scraped off.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 4-day history of white lesions in his mouth and pain while chewing. He was diagnosed with non-Hodgkin lymphoma 8 months ago and is currently receiving his fourth cycle of chemotherapy. He has a 15-year history of smoking half a pack of cigarettes daily. Vital signs are normal. On examination, he has cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy. Oral examination reveals white plaques on his tongue and buccal mucosa that bleed when scraped with gauze. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although culture of the lesions can be performed to diagnose oropharyngeal candidiasis, it is only used in recurrent or refractory disease to determine possible resistance because results usually take time. This is the patient's first episode of oral thrush, and there are no indicators of unusual or resistant Candida species.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical corticosteroids are used in the treatment of severe aphthous stomatitis, a disease that manifests with painful oral ulcers covered by a yellow fibrinous pseudomembrane. White plaques that can be scraped off are not typical of the disease, making oral candidiasis more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

A biopsy of the lesion would be indicated in the case of suspected oral leukoplakia, a precancerous lesion, in which malignancy should be ruled out. While the white lesions of leukoplakia resemble oropharyngeal candidiasis and are common in tobacco users, they are usually asymptomatic and cannot be scraped off.

D) CORRECT:

Topical antifungal therapy (e.g., troches, mucoadhesive buccal tablets, pastilles) is considered first-line for most patients with oropharyngeal candidiasis. Preferred topical agents include clotrimazole, miconazole, and nystatin. Oral fluconazole is also used, most commonly in patients with moderate to severe symptoms.

The diagnosis of oropharyngeal candidiasis is most often clinical. KOH test and/or tissue culture are usually reserved for patients with inconclusive clinical findings. HIV testing should be performed in patients with no identifiable risk factors for oropharyngeal candidiasis.

Key learning point: Oropharyngeal candidiasis is typically diagnosed clinically and treated first-line with topical antifungal agents such as nystatin, clotrimazole, or miconazole.
Image Description:

Yellow-white cottage cheese-like plaques are visible on the inflamed oropharyngeal mucosa.

These white plaques are pathognomonic of oral candidiasis (oral thrush), an opportunistic infection caused by Candida albicans.

E) INCORRECT:

Systemic fluconazole therapy can be used to treat patients with moderate to severe oropharyngeal candidiasis. However, oral rather than intravenous fluconazole is recommended for these patients. Intravenous fluconazole therapy is usually reserved for patients with esophageal candidiasis who cannot tolerate oral therapy or patients with systemic candidiasis.
questions.hint: White plaques on the oral mucosa that can be scraped off are suggestive of oropharyngeal candidiasis. Further common findings include pain when eating, loss of taste, and a cottony feeling in the mouth. Candida albicans infections most commonly affect immunocompromised individuals, e.g., patients with hematologic malignancies.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with HIV presents with a 4-day history of throat pain and difficulty swallowing. He describes pain when swallowing both liquids and solids, with a burning sensation that extends into his chest. Physical examination shows white patches on the tongue and inner cheeks. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Caspofungin is a second-line agent reserved for fluconazole-refractory infections or if fluconazole is contraindicated. This medication is not appropriate as initial therapy for esophageal candidiasis.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- The combination of oral white patches with retrosternal odynophagia in a patient with HIV indicates esophageal candidiasis. First-line treatment is oral fluconazole for 14–21 days to ensure adequate treatment of both oropharyngeal and esophageal disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical nystatin is appropriate for isolated oropharyngeal candidiasis but is inadequate for esophageal involvement. The retrosternal burning pain with swallowing suggests esophageal candidiasis requiring systemic therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical clotrimazole is appropriate for isolated oropharyngeal candidiasis but is inadequate for esophageal involvement. The retrosternal burning pain with swallowing suggests esophageal candidiasis requiring systemic therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Amphotericin B is a second-line agent reserved for fluconazole-refractory infections or if fluconazole is contraindicated. This medication is not appropriate as initial therapy for esophageal candidiasis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with a history of recent bowel resection with primary anastomosis presents to the emergency department with fever and abdominal pain. Vital signs are T, 39.1°C (102.4°F), P, 115; BP 110/70 mm Hg. Laboratory studies reveal leukocytosis with bandemia. CT abdomen shows a fluid collection adjacent to the anastomosis concerning for anastomotic leak. IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibacterial therapy with piperacillin-tazobactam and vanomycin are administered. What additional medication is the most appropriate to administer?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While amphotericin B is an effective antifungal agent with broad activity against Candida species, it is not the preferred first-line treatment for intraabdominal candidiasis due to significant drug toxicity and should only be used when there is limited availability of other agents or intolerance to other antifungals.

B) INCORRECT:

Clindamycin is an antibacterial agent that provides coverage against anaerobic bacteria and some gram-positive bacteria, however it has no antifungal activity and would not address the risk of intraabdominal candidiasis in this patient with anastomotic leak.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient with recent bowel surgery and anastomotic leak is at high risk for intraabdominal candidiasis. Echinocandins like caspofungin are the preferred first-line antifungal therapy for intraabdominal candidiasis and should be initiated empirically in patients with evidence of infection and risk factors for intraabdominal candidiasis.

D) INCORRECT:

Tobramycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic that provides gram-negative bacterial coverage, however, it has no antifungal activity and would not address the risk of intraabdominal candidiasis in this patient with anastomotic leak.

E) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole provides anaerobic bacterial coverage and is commonly used for intraabdominal infections, however, it has no antifungal activity and would not address the risk of intraabdominal candidiasis in this patient with anastomotic leak.

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department for a rash for the past few days. His mother states he has been acting appropriately and making a normal amount of wet diapers. Vital signs are normal. His examination is shown and no oral lesions are noted on exam. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical hydrocortisone is a low-potency corticosteroid used for irritant diaper dermatitis, however, the rash is more consistent with a Candida diaper dermatitis requiring different treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Cephalexin is an antibiotic that can be used to treat cellulitis, however, the rash is more consistent with a Candida diaper dermatitis requiring different treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Mupirocin is a topical antibiotic that can be used to treat cellulitis, however, the rash is more consistent with a Candida diaper dermatitis requiring different treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral fluconazole is an effective systemic antifungal agent, however, it is not first-line therapy for candidal diaper dermatitis where a topical antifungal thearpy is preferred.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- Topical nystatin is a first-line antifungal agent specifically indicated for candidal diaper dermatitis. This patient presents with classic features of candidal superinfection including dark red erythema, satellite lesions, and involvement of intertriginous areas.
